text: A high aerial view of the Amazon, winding a as far as the can see through the planet's least-known rain forest. The _last flare of the setting sun casts an amber glow.

Dark water reflects the moon. POV AT WATER LEVEL, slowly weaving toward the kerosene running lights of a tradition AMAZON RIVERBOAT sitting slightly lopsided in the water. may catch a glimpse of a body lying by the river's edge n the boat.

The POV glides in as the eceasional squawk cf a parrot or . Chatter of a monkey punctuates the otherwise ominous si of the jungle. Now circles the riverboat, then dips underwater...we should see that ‘the BOAT'S ENGINE is bat and non-functional, beyond repair. SFX of the engine gxinding, someone trying desperately, futilely to get it started.

Faded lettering on her shallow draft hull informs us she' the “RAMONA". A poacher's pride and joy, stocked with NET TRAPS, CANISTERS: tools of the trade, but in this instanc chosen with a single prey in mind. From inside the CREW CABIN we can just hear a SINGLE, EXHAUSTED VOICE, speakin Portugese, and, very low on the soundtrack, STRANGE MUSIC Brazilian pop, playing half-speed... . “INT. RAMONA CREW CABIN NIGHT The musica bit louder; the VOICE, still off-screen, more obviously desperate. THE CAMERA takes in the cramped quarters, illuminated by the flickering light of an OIL L There is a single chair and a small table and FOUR BUNKS, each one showing evidence of having been recently occupied...a duffel bag near one, clothes strewn about — another, yet another unmade with a BOOMBOX resting near t Pillow. THE MUSIC comes from the boombox: we see a tape ~ spinning, slower and slower, as the batteries die... The camera comes to a rest on the source of the voice: an older INDIAN MAN, his face scarred and glistening with th sweat of fear. He sits before a SHORTWAVE RADIO, frantica (CONTINUED )

attempting to bring the dead piece of hardware to life-- twisting the dial, babbling into the mike. All in vain: w don't even hear static from the radio. .- A SUDDEN SMALL BUMP shakes the boat, and the POACHER. He freezes for a moment, then quickly rises, grabbing a NEAR GUN and a HAMMER. He moves to the door, passing a picture tacked on the wall: ‘THE PICTURE shows THREE MEN, proudly holding a LARGE SNAKE, about twenty feet long. The SNAKE mazzled and harnassed with high tech trapping apparati. W recognize one of the men as the poacher...the second man Indian features. The third is a particulerly cocky . ‘Caucasian, wearing a T-shirt with the ROLLING STONES TRADEMARK tongue on it. EXT. BOAT DECK WIGHT. The Poacher dares to emerge. He looks around, firearm leveled. He mumbles in Portugese...threats mixed with ple punctuated by prayers, the ramblings of a schizophrenic.. he crosses the deck, his eyes darting to the river. S-SHAPED WAVES roll across the dark water's surface and l against the hull, rocking the boat. He gets on all fours uses the hammer claw to pry planks from the wooden deck. A bucket rolls across the deck. He spins, FIRES, CLANGS a hole through it. Hesitates, goes back to his chore, still mumbling.. He tears up some deck planks, drags them into cabin and slams the door. We hear now HAMMERING SOUNDS.
The poacher begins to nail wood planks to the doorframe.. POV-- UNDERWATER | ‘ The unseen presence seems to be. casing the boat, tooking the most valnerable area of attack.

’ Nailed inside the cabin, the poacher backs to the table taking a swig of liquor before moving back to the radio. he simply hits it. And now we hear a sputter of static. — HOPE. He picks up the mike and begins to talk into it but just that moment: .

head_text.subj: SOMETHING BUMPS UP UNDERNEATH THE FLOORBOARDS. A SUDDEN

text: JOLT, strong enough to knock the radio off the table, whi shatters into pieces when it hits the floor. The Poacher' (CONTINUED )
10 Ne : Shooting script - December 1 3.

eyes, wide with terror, lock on the floorboards. More . BUMPING AND THUMPING. Little by little the old floorboard are giving way, the rusty nails shaking loose. The Poache leaps across the cramped room and begins prying off the planks which he'd just nailed over the door. The floorboards are buckling up and splintering. The Poac whimpers and cries, his hands bloodied and fingernails sp as he yanks the boards from the door. Suddenly, the floorboards all splinter up -- just. as the Poacher frees himself out the door. : “ :
The Poacher scrambles up the few steep steps to the cabin roof. He looks behind him and seés something terrifying. climbs to the top of the mast rising above the cabin. .

He's totally crazed. Lips aquiver. Sweat streaming. He looks down, gasps in terror and quickly pulls his legs up far as he can -~ something's coming. He starts to recite LORD'S PRAYER in Portugese as he takes the GUN and shoots into the water-- once, twice, three times. Again, in vain. The boat is being violently rocked by the attacking creature. He checks his gun, sees that he has o bullet left. He is beyond fear now: seems somehow at peac as he puts the gun to his head, finishing his prayer.
We are a long distance from the Ramona, barely making out small form on the quiet, black river.
Ame'm,... A SINGLE. SHOT.echoes. And we . FADE OUT.

Like before, a high aerial view of the Amazon, but this t civilization encroaches. A sprawling city has edged its jagged claw into the jungle -- urban concrete nibbling at Massive green. A silver jet slopes down and lands on the edge of the cit é 10
Shooting seript - December 1 4.

C) The VAN slams on its brakes, screeching to a stop, bar \ missing an INDIAN MAN lugging a large basket of fruit. occupants of the Van lurch against the seats. The Indian Man moves on, after giving the driver of the v an international hand signal, and the van continues to navigate the clatter and color of Manaus: NATIVES in feat walking among CITY PEOPLE in business suits...KIDS playin soccer in a muddy field that is flanked by modern office buildings....STREET VENDORS selling everything they own....STREET WALKERS selling everything imaginable. see 11A EXT. DOCK - DAY 11a ’ The van passes across a bridge onto the dock teeming wi PEOPLE coming and going. CRATES filled with electronic go soda, beer, BARGES heavily laden. BOATS of all sizes and shapes -- RIVERBOATS preparing for a long journey, hammoc swinging from their decks, maybe a band plays as one riverboat pulls out. The van pulls up next to a waiting SPEEDBOAT The ARIAU JU TOWER HOTEL printed across the stern and disgorges the jostled occupants. First out is GARY, a handsome American © shoots a look at TERRI PORTER, an attractive woman in h ” twenties, confident, tough, independent. Terri's been r in the front passenger seat: GARY'S expression seems to s "What have you gotten us in to". GARY helps DENISE KALBERG, early twenties, a fresh, small town scrubbed quality about her, as they unload their equipment. From their body language and playful manner it apparent that they are lovers. Denise wears a funky jewel erucifix from her neck.
As the speedboat leaves the city, we see the two great ri of the Amazon merging -- the brown water of THE AMAZON an the black water of the RIO NEGRO -- fingers of currents distinctly intertwined.
Ov. — ed 12 13
Shooting Script - December 1 5.-

THE SPEEDBOAT stops in front of the ARIAU JUNGLE TOWER HO an astonishing piece of architecture which rises out of t jungle like an elaborate treehouse. Terri, Denise, and Ga step out and start to unload their luggage. Denise throws arms around Gary, excited. They take a moment to share a passionate kiss. Terri watches them for a beat, wistful, before carrying her gear into the hotel. .

Gary and Denise lead the way down one of the catwalks. Bi of every color flit in the jungle canopy. Monkeys chatter from the trees. They reach a room and Denise unlocks the door. She turns to Terri and hands her a room key.
I don't think we'll see you for dinner.
(playfully) She's gonna tie me to the bed.
Handeuffs, Gary. Handcuffs. Denise playfully shoves Gary into the room and closes the door. Terri smiles wryly and walks on.

Terri comes upon a platform with a clear view of the rive she sees a young black man slouching on a camera case. Th case is marked with the logo for NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC. He DANNY. Terri sPproaches hin. :
You must ‘be the cameraman. Danny peeks out from above his Raybans.
Where's the director?
That'd be me. DANNY . You're kidding me, right? You're much too short to be a director. You got to be tall. You can't possibly be the director.
Shooting Script - December 1 6. 13
It's my first time. They waived the height requirement.

Oh no! You're a first timer! Wet behind the ears...rookie...and short! TERRI . - You got a problem with that? Yeah. I got a problem with that. Let. me tell-you, when they called and asked me to do this job I turned it down flat. I've been on location for five months and I was startin' to get used to livin' without plumbing. Danny. breaks into a huge grin. He stands
But when they’ said my old pal from college was directing.... and gives her a warm hug.
- You couldn't resist. ;
Hey. I have to be here. This is your big break. I wouldn't miss it.
I wasn't coming down here without you.
Guess I. should've asked for more money. oo TERRI “(smiling back). We would've paid it. Danny stands and picks up his gear. DANNY . Who's the egghead in charge?
Dr. Steven Cale. (CONTINUED )
14 ed oo,
Shooting Script - December 1 7.
Isn't he the guy you....?
That's all in the past. No more messy romance for me. I'm footloose and fancy free.
Well alright. We're gonna have some. fun.
or die trying.

Wight encroaches. and the jungle begins to come alive wit sounds.’ Danny sits at a table drinking a beer and smokin Dannemann Speciale (small cigars native to Brazil). Gary enters looking exhausted and walks over to Danny.
Hey. How's it goin'?
Just kickin' back, feedin' the mosquitos. Danny extends his hand.

Danny Cameraman. Gary Sound. Pleased to make your acquaintance. They shake hands. Gary sits. At Danny's signal a Waiter . brings a couple of beers to the table and hands it to Gar Gary vigorously swats the bugs that swarm around him. GARY . Christ. These bugs...who invited them? DANNY . They only take a pint. I donate every night. Better to get it over with in one sitting than have them peck at you all day. . ( CONTINUED)
Shooting script - December 1 8.
Gary wipes his face with a bandana.
They must be attracted to the sweat. How is it this hot at night?
Just think of it as New York in August. Gary takes a long pull on the beer.
You from the City?
Brooklyn.

Yeah!? Me too. Imagine that. Two guys from Brooklyn in the middle of the . jungle. DANNY . It's not just a job, it's an adventure. GARY . Yeah, well, the pay sucks on this adventure. Denise walks into the bar.
Gary? Gary?
(to Danny) © . But the fringe benefits are excellent. Gary. quickly exits. Danny finishes his beer.

In the pitch black of the jungle at night, Terri sits ata bamboo desk, illuminated by her laptop computer. The wall behind her is not wood but actually a large piece of scre and the sounds and smells of the jungle drift into the ro She hears the eerie calls of bat hawks hunting over the river, a few thumps on her roof... Just as she's starting get the creeps, there's a knock at the door. She flicks o the light. : (CONTINUED )
15 Shooting Script - December 1 9.
Terri opens the door + to reveal, DR. STEVEN CALE (33), & handsome, articulate, and passionate professor of Cultura Anthropology. He holds a wrapped package. in his hands.
Steven! When did you get in?
Yesterday. I've been out talking to some guides. Hoping they might know the whereabouts of our tribe. He hands her the package.
For you. A peace offering.
We're not at war. Cale sits on the bed.
Then it's for luck. Terri unwraps the package and reveals a intricately woven wreath of twigs, dried flowers; and feathers.
It's beautiful. , CALE . Shirishama. I bought it from a river trader. It has some ceremonial significance between lovers. Terri gives Cale a look.
. (pareastic) a : Really? Would that. ceremonial significance mean commitment? Or is monogamy not a word in the shirishama ~ vocabulary? Cale lets out a groan.
How long are you going to hold that against me? I just wasn't ready. That doesn't mean I'm not ready now.
Shooting script - December 1 - 10, 15 CONTINUED: (2) oO “45 Terri sits back in front of her computer.
What if I'm not ready?
Cale looks distressed. He sighs and looks ont the window.
(sighing) Maybe this whole thing is a big mistake.

- Look. I'm here for strictly professional reasons. And that's a promise. I thought we could work together. TERRI . It's not just about us, it's about the Shirishama. They're out there. Completely isolated. They have their own customs, myths, religion. Unique. Unlike anything we've experienced. What if we pollute that?

We're professionals... We're making a documentary. We can do this without ‘ disrupting the tribe. We've been working a) on this for too long to stop now. And ( despite everything that's happened, I think we make a great team.
She chews on her thumbnail and considers what he's saying
I know. I know. I've just get a creepy feeling. Sorry. He stands and puts his hand on her shoulder. CALE ‘ Get over it. This is an important Project to both of us. Terri opens her door.
You're right. I'11 see you “an the morning. | Cale exits.
Shooting script - December 1 11.

Early morning -- the first light of day. A massive bulky object slides out of the derkness, moving toward CAMERA. It creeks eerily as we begin to make out w it is: cena nate Cee tated barge that has been up and down the Amazon many times.
"RED-EYE" MATEO stands on the deck of the boat, sneaking early-morning swig from his trusty, dented flask. He list with obvious disinterest as CALE shows him something on a map.
We'll motor approximately a hundred and fifty miles upstream on the Negro, then proceed down this tributary to the Abufari reserve. Mateo shakes his head "No"...
Why not?
Rapids. Shallows. We go this way. Mateo points to another route on the map.
Excuse me Captain Mateo, but since I'm the one paying the bills,. perhaps | you'l1 gee clear to go my. way. “Mateo lights a 2 cigarette and looks at the map.
‘No: problem. It's: your boat. And Iam just - a hired hand. We go your way. Only I . insist we take a detour....here. Otherwise I cannot be responsible. He points to a specific tributary.

Shooting Script - December 1 / 212. 17A’ EXT. HOTEL WATERFRONT — DAY : 17A C) Terri walks toward the fifty five-foot barge of rusted SH and peeling paint. It's as flat as a pancake with a sq -bow and stern. There's a raised, wooden pilot house at o end and a rusted crane at the stern. The boat rides only inches above the waterline, burdened with drums of diesel fuel, coils of rope, and supply trunks. Terri walks over to Cale and hands hima page of script. Behind them the crew sets up equipment on the boat. Danny moves back and forth with his light meter. Gary fiddles w cables and tapes. Denise oversees the loading of equipmen and supplies, checking them off on her clipboard.
Steven? Can you look this over?
Sure. Sleep well?
Fine. Where's Westridge? I know he checked in.

He' i be along. Beauty sleep you know. | — WARREN WESTRIDGE, late forties, barely sweating in his suit, is a distinguished and imposing man; his supercilio nature is apparent as he guides the BELLBOY who is carryi an imposing stack of monogrammed luggage. ‘WESTRIDGE . Careful! Careful! Just because we're in the wilds doesn't mean you.can sling my luggage -any which. way. Westridge watches as his luggage thuds on the deck next t Denise.
You there! Young woman! Stow that in my room. 7 DENISE . . I'm not the bellhop. I'm the Production Manager.
: Shooting Script - December 1 13.
. Then you can manage my things into my . OY room. ~ . Terri approaches him.

Mr. Westridge? Terri Porter. WESTRIDGE ~ . Ahi The director. as cadet. Professor Cale lent me some of your short films. You have a modicum of. talent, but I will not ~ let you get away with any self indulgent _prattle on this shoot. Terri is awed by his pomposity.

Well, thanks. (BEAT) Welcome aboard, I guess. . , WESTRIDGE. And getting aboard is just what I'm going to do. It's too bloody hot. Are we exactly on the equator? : Terri-and Cale exchange a look as Westridge clambers on © and into one of the cabins, banging his luggage against anything that gets in his way. Cale jumps on board and straps some diving equipment secu to a railing. Danny sits on his camera case waiting for t shot. Gary and Denise stand next to him.
Diving gear? .
It's. a*hobby. Terri takes a snapshot from shore and jumps aboard as Westridge comes steaming out of his cabin.
I do*not sweat the little things, Mr. Cale, but my living guarters are uninhabitable, and that's not a little thing. Are you listening to me? (CONTINUED )
Shooting seript - December 1
We'll see what we can do.
How and when?
We'll knock out a wall, Westridge. I'm sure the captain will have no. problem with that. Would you like an entertainment system installed as well? -
Ihave a contract, and I will walk off this boat--
Now's the time to do it, then. Westridge doesn't like what he's hearing.
You've got five minutes to think about it, and then we debark. Go think. WESTRIDGE . I...I will think. TI have thought. And I will think some more. He walks off, and Cale looks to Terri. She shrugs.
Ready to cast off! Terri and Cale snap to. This is the moment they've been waiting for. :
‘CALE Alright everybody! Double check your gear! And pray you didn't forget the bug spray!

text: Terri stands with Danny, Gary, and Denise. (CONTINUED)

Shooting script - December 1 is.
(shouting) Mr. Westridge! We're ready for you! Cale hands Terri the page with an approving nod as Westri comes lumbering out of his cabin.
Thanks. Here's the script for the establishing shot. She hands him the paper. Westridge skims it.
Fine. Fine. Fine.

(switching into gear) : Alright! Let's get this in the can! She leads Westridge over to his mark. Danny checks the li Gary struggles with the Nagra and boom mike. The cable sn around his legs and is stuck. He tugs violently on it.
Ready Mr. Westridge? Westridge nods.
(snapping) I'm not ready! Gary whips the mike cable around angrily.
(surly) Just give me a goddamn second here! Terri cooly waits until Gary untangles the cord and nods ‘approval.
Roll film! sound!
Rollin'.
Speed. Marker. Gary dips the mike into camera view and thumps it with hi hand. Terri signals Westridge, who clears his throat. (CONTINUED)
Shooting Script - December 1 : 16.

Our adventure begins one thousand miles from the mouth of the mighty Amazon, deep in the heart of the rainforest. We will travel by river barge up through shallow tributaries and unexplored backwaters in search of the elusive "People of the Mist", the Shirishama Tribe. The Shirishama have lived in complete isolation and harmony with nature for hundreds of years. Dr. Steven Cale, a - leading expert on this tribe, will be accompanying us on our trek to help unravel the mysteries of the Sbirishama. (BEAT) God, that's a mouthful.
Cut. Ok. Westridge starts to walk off. Terri-just stares at him. Westridge moves to the front of the barge carrying a wine _ bottle and offers a benediction to the river.
For God, Queen, and Country! We Prey for a safe return! He then smashes the wine bottle against the bow. He turns and sees the puzzled looks of the crew.

A cheap chardonnay. He goes into his cabin. Danny shuts off his camera and tu to Terri. DANKY © Having. fun yet? - Terri.rolls her eyes. Danny and Gary begin wrapping their equipment against. the humidity. Cale stands at’ the rail watching the river. Terri grabs Denise and takes her asid
He is an experienced soundman, isn't he?
Terri...I wouldn't bring a deadbeat on a shoot even if he is drop-dead adorable. (CONTINUED)
Shooting Script - December 1 an
Look. I'm sorry..I don't mean overreact. Maybe I'm letting his reputation get to me.
(defensive ) You don't know him.
You're right. But one pain in the ass is enough and Westridge deserves that honor. ° If Gary doesn't get his act her...I'11 run sound and we'll leave him at the first village we come to.
He'll be fine and I can take care of myself. cur 0:

AERIAL SHOT wo . 18.A ‘The boat travels across the Rio Negro. The rising sun ca glow across the vast expanse of water. Terri nudges Danny points out some pink river dolphins in the water. Danny p down for a shot. They pass one or two boats and turns int smaller tributary.

The river has thickened, and there are no other boats in sight. . Danny stands near the back of the barge with a c on his shoulder as he films the -hot, sticky jungle. Gary and’ Denise are on the port side, he's taping sounds the shore. She's making notes in her expense book. We hea “the exotic shrills of “birds and the cries:of small anim ph
Late afternoon. The barge continues upriver. (CONTINUED )

22 Shooting Script - December 1 18. CONTINUED: ry Danny is shooting more film of the jungle. Gary adjusts t shotgun microphone to get the sounds of monkeys in the to of the trees. He hands Denise an extra set of headphones. She puts them on and her face registers the otherworldly - sounds she hears -- monkeys screeching -- they're spook may be the encroaching rain. The air crackles. Westridge looks for a place to sit, but everything seems filthy. He takes a handkerchief from his pocket and spreads it on a suitable spot. ANGLE: . ce - 2aas The clouds seem to suddenly expand, turning the color of lead, darkening the immediate area. A BOLT OF LIGHTNING SPLITS THE SKY, and everyone RUNS FOR COVER as a torrenti tropic storm pours sheets of rain onto the barge. Mateo struggles in the strong wind to pilot the barge up churning brown river. Everyone hides from the rain under leaking canvas tenting that is draped across the deck. They all look numb and miserable and vulnerable to the powers of nature.

The torrential rains continue. Mateo squints into the win and is barely able to see the shoreline because the rain so heavy. But he's looking very carefully. The barge rounds a bend, and Danny sees it first: the sha of something in the mist.

Hey! Over there! A BOAT, gray and heavy, tilting in the water. One by one, the others see the boat... It appears to be abandoned as ‘sags heavily, anchored but lurching from the churning wa Terri points: aman stands on ‘the deck of the boat, his ‘loose clothing flapping in the wind. Soaked and desperat he: waves ‘his arms frantically at them, shouting words t cannot hear. . Terri calls to Mateo over the howling wind
Get close to his boat! We'll bring him aboard! ‘
No. You trust nobody on these waters.
22 . Shooting Script - December a 19.

We can't leave him stranded. Cale squints at the vision of a man waving desperately in + storm, a look of recognition and dread crosses his face looks to Mateo, who is simply waiting for instructions.

(subdued ) "Pull over to his boat. Mateo maneuvers toward the crippled boat. Danny has his camera on his shoulder. Gary and Denise are taping the vicious sounds of the winds and rain. Mateo smiles ever s slyly. The form becomes a man as the two boats get closer. PAUL SARONE is tall, strong and handsome with a commanding physical presence, obvious even as he stands soaked. - The two boats come close, Gary grabs.a rope and heaves across the gap to Sarone. Gary wraps it around a cleat as Sarone pulls the barge a little closer.

Catch! Sarone throws a duffel bag to Gary, who catches it. Then another. Gary plops the duffel bags down. Sarone dives in river and Cale, Gary, and Terri haul him aboard. He is bo hot and cold, shivering as they lead him beneath some tenting. Gary pours brandy into a cup and Denise wraps an about his shoulders. Sarone drinks down the brandy with o fast gulp, barely taking note of the people around him. TERRI oo . . You okay? . .
I. think so. Storm surge pushed me into the shallows, my propeller caught a ‘rock. God knows how long I'd have been stuck here. : ‘CALE We can't take you back to Manaus. We're headed up river. :
If you can just get me to the next village, I know the people. They'1l help me fix my boat. (CONTINUED )
Shooting Script - pecember 1 20.
Glances all around: no one has any problems with that.
I'd really appreciate it. sorry if I'm any trouble.
Don't apologize. We're at the mercy of our machines. Yours broke. . Danny continues filming. Sarone notices the camera and gr

Am I going to be on the news? Sarone's good humor disarms the crew. Everyone laughs exc Mateo. Sarone looks up to Mateo. Mateo regards him with s mysterious knowledge: he knows this man, or men like him.
Later.now, the storm has ended. The water is calm and the - has cleared. The boat is anchored along the shore. Dann stands at the back of the boat filming. Terri, Cale, and Westridge watch as:

You saved my life! The least I can do is cook dinner. SARONE. stands stock still in the river. He holds a crude spear above his head. Suddenly, and with tremendous speed Sarone strikes. He pulls a large, violently flapping, fis out of the water. He holds it up. .

Fish river style. Sarone climbs into the boat. - He whips out a knife and efficiently guts and cleans the fish. Gary and Denise have come out of their cabin. Gary watches, mesmerized by Sarone's skill. TERRI ' . Ever work in a sushi bar, Mr. Sarone?
It's safer to eat cooked food. (CONTINUED)
iN ()
shooting Script - pecember 1 21. How long. have you been on the river, Mr. Sarone?
Seems like forever. I think it's been about four years.
Where're. you from?
St. Louis.
What brought you here?
(laughing) Fate. Bad karma. I started out studying for the Priesthood. After spending so much time inside I figured I needed to get out. See the real world. Somehow I ended up here. Guess I fit in.
And what does a failed Priest do in the jungle?
I catch reptiles: for zoos and collectors. Whatever they want.
Poaching?
Poaching is illegal. I hunt and trap. The fish filleted, Sarone rinses the fish with bottled wa and then moves to the stove. Terri and the others watch, intrigued by this man.
And now you're hunting?
Snakes. Mostly.
I hate snakes.
Shooting Script —~ pecember 1 22.
SARONE ° And you all? What are you | hunting? WESTRIDGE . . We're not hunting anything. We're making a filn.
About the Shirishama.
- | The People of The Mist.
You know of them?
I've seen them. WESTRIDGE . And so slurs every other river rat after five whiskeys in any bar in Manaus.

(laughing) Five whiskeys? That's breakfast on the river. (BEAT) How are you going to find them? CALE . The Shirishama follow the seasons and the eclipses. As part of their religion. We're following the lunar calendar.
They also must eat. Religion sometimes takes back seat to hunger. Could you hand me that skillet? And some oil? .* TERRI . There’ 8 some truth to that, steven. Cale shoots her a look.

-Would.a salad go well with ‘fish river style'? SARONE wt Perfect. Denise hands him the skillet. Sarone expertly salts and : ss the large fish, rubs some oil on it, and drope it in. the skillet. The fish pops and sizzles. (CONTINUED )
shooting Script - pecember 1 23.
Sarone picks up some small red fruits, .smashes them, pop little black seeds into the pan with the fish. Denise was some vegetables with bottled water.
What're those?
Chicha. They taste like peanuts. Cale and Terri exchange a look. Danny puts his camera dow He walks over to the cooking fish and inhales deeply.
Now that smells good. Sarone smiles.
When did you see the tribe?
About a month ago.
Can you lead us to them?
We don't need any help, thank you very much.
Don't be so hasty Westridge. We might need a little help.
Look. You've been very kind. I feel I'm getting in the way... : Whatever help you'can give us, whatever you can tell us about the river....
I owe you. If there is a spare hammock, a good night's sleep is all I need, and in the morning I can show you where I last saw the Shirishama.
Shooting Script - December 1 24.
C) The remains of dinner lay scattered around the table. \ Westridge kills bugs with a spray can. Gary and Denise, _ loaded down with sound equipment climb ashore. Danny st out his cigarillo.
Fed the ‘bugs. Time for me to turn in. ‘Good night. Danny stands and goes into his cabin..
We're going to collect some wild sound.
Be careful.
Yeah. It's a jungle out there.
Listen to it. It's beautiful. Gary and Denise hold hands like teenage lovers as they. l the boat, stepping onto shore. Each carries a box as they walk into the jungle. Cy ,
There's nothing like falling in leve.
I hear Gary does it at least once on every job.

However unsavory, at least his reputation is known. It's the hitch hiker that concerns me. Unbeknownst to them, Sarone stands twenty feet back, watc them, concerned. Westridge leans close to Terri and Cale. ‘WESTRIDGE . He's a poacher by his own admission.
He's a resource, Warren.
Shooting Script - December 1 25.
He knows the river.
So find out what he knows then and deposit him at the first opportunity. I'm with the captain-- you can't trust a stranger, and I do not trust him.

EXT. SAW MILL - DAY aul Danny limps with Terri toward the mill. They walk past th . heavily crumpled jeeps and mangled wreckage. The damage bizarre, otherworldly.
Jesus...what happened? panny and Terri exchange a look, and « a shudder. "they k what happened. . Terri walks past a large incinerator, with a tall smokest to the front doors of the mill. .

Dust and filth everywhere. Danny and Terri look down the length of the mill. Massive sawblades stand silent. Shaft grayish light penetrate the gloom. Stacks of lumber, cind blocks, rebar, crates, and other material are scattered i random heaps. The floor is littered with sawdust, scraps wood, metal bindings, etc. Opposite the saw, connected by series of fractured catwalks, are the deserted mill offic Everywhere they look are signs that. the jungle has quiok reclaimed the property. .  omrrmuD)  ——rnansemeeeesneemnnemmmmmnnnennnnnnnemms tans iscsi

shooting Script ~ pecember 1 "89. 122 CONTINUED: ‘ : 112 As they walk through the mill a massive’ shadow shifts ev slightly behind them. Danny turns just as the shadow stil -he sees a‘ defunct telephone on the wall next to a faded Playboy centerfold. Terri picks up the phone and puts it her ear.

Didn't pay their bill. They walk towards the back of the building and stop short when they see a large wood pulp mountain made up of rotte scraps and discards on the back wall. The mountain blocks doors or windows in the back. .

What the? . Danny looks at the pulp mountain and it seems to be alive It is actually moving. It only takes a heartbeat for them realize that the wood pulp is swarmed by living anacondas -that squirm and writhe. They are young, no longer than s feet, nesting in the pulp.
Babies.

(unnerved) Whatever. Let's get out of here. They move back towards the front and see an old incinerat furnace, part-of the massive chimey that rises out of the mill. Next to the furnace: a stack of 55 gallon fuel drum Danny shuffles quickly to a stack of fuel drums against t wall. He wrestles one of the heavy drums into position.
Here we go.

Let's get them to the.boat. Danny looks down at his leg. The exertion has opened his wound. » DANNY Ob man. Terri notices. She takes off her shirt (she wears a T-shi beneath) and expertly t ties a tourniquet around his woun flow is stopped. (CONTINUED ) ’

Hey. You go to jungle survival school or : | oY’ . something? — : TERRI Nah. I saw a guy do it on the subway. They tip a drum on its side and roll it towards the door. 113 EXT. MILL - DAY o, 113 They come out. of the building with the fuel drum and immediately see something unsettling: The Boat has drifted away from the dock to the opposite shore, a couple hundred feet upstream, where it sways in current, caught in a tangle of overhanging tree limbs.

I set the anchor... | ‘Terri rans towards the river. Danny jogs, limping, after Danny reaches her and they stand, next to a clump of tree watching the boat drift. The sudden horrible reality of t situation becomes clear. . . OS eae)
a ‘(hoarse whisper) Sarone! Suddenly a voice, a movement from behind.
No need to be discreet. Danny and Terri spin towards the voice and are met head o with the butt of a rifle.

Terri and Danny sit, still unconscious, back to back in t middle of the factory floor. They are bound ankle and wri by gaffers tape and appear to be sitting in the middle of large net that has been spread on out on the floor. Saron stands in front of them holding a bucket.
——————— rT a f : . shooting Script - December 1 . 91.
Rise and shine! : WJ Sarone dumps the contents of the bucket on them. Danny . Terri wake immediately as the sticky liquid hits their
(spitting) Abh. Man! SARONE - . A little monkey blood. Terri's eyes burn into Sarone.
I'm going to. kill you Sarone! I swear to God. I am going to kill you. She squirms and thrashes trying to break free.
That's good. Excellent. You know the secret is to put the hook just deep enough into the worm so that it is still alive. Bait needs to wiggle. Your heat...the vibrations...the smell of fresh blood.
You are out of your fucking mind!

(shrugging) I'm not .a man of science like your Mr. Cale, he's not a believer. I'ma man of the river and I don't have. to believe. (BEAT) I know.. Sarone slinks off into the shadows. Silence. The air grow still. Shadows shift against the walls. Suddenly Terri realizes, as Danny already has, ae complet vulnerability of their situation. They both begin to squi and strain against the "shackles".
It's no use. This is the best tape you ean buy. TERRI lets out an animal scream of rage and frustration.

As she screams the camera pulls back and up to the furthe corner of the room. Danny and Terri sit together, specks the floor, like pieces of cheese for some. gigantic mouse camera keeps pulling back, through a window, up and out o the. bnilding, back and back further until the sawmill be to blend into the jungle.

A long TONGUE flicks ont, entering our view from the uppe left corner. Sensing, smelling, seeing... The CAMERA DIVES towards the mill, through branches and walls, taking just seconds to frame Danny and Terri, jast we left them, struggling in vain...
Continue to thrash and struggle. Terri looks up and sees saw blades on the level above them.
Think we can make it up that ladder? Danny cranes his neck. Knows what she's thinking.
Yeah. Maybe. They wriggle across the floor -- without the use of arms legs they, ironically, move = Like snakes.

Almost to the bottom of the ladder, determined, it looks this just. might work...until we see the length of rope t is tied to Danny's ankles and is now stretched taut, its opposite end tied to a wooden post. Danny thunks his head against the floor in frustration. : Terri squints up at the saw blade only a short ladder cli away. And suddenly, it‘s dark as night, as if someone has just turned off the lights. Danny looks up at the skylights. He and Terri see the silhouette of a MASSIVE ANACONDA slithering across the ro and into the building through a high window. Terri gasps. (CONTINUED )
Shooting Script - December 1 93.

The snake flicks its. tongue out, ty Picking up their sce slithering through the window and down the entire length the wall...it keeps coming and coming, and for the first we see its astounding size -- forty plus feet. The catwal and ladders strain and creak under its immense weight. The snake drops to the factory floor and mves towards the terrified pair. Danny and Terri scoot away from the snake fast as they can, tearing and biting desperately at their bindings. . The snake comes quickly up to them, stops and rises over preparing to strike...mouth open...dripping fangs bared.. The snake lunges forward with blinding speed. Danny and T attempt to roll out of the way. but the snake scoots towa them, quickly coils around both of them, and starts to — squeeze.

(screaming) Sarone! Her scream is cut off by the power of the constriction. : Sarone appears, swinging from a rope. The rope is attache a pulley and Sarone's weight quickly pulls a large net up from the floor and around the snake. The snake, distracte and angry, thrashes violently against the net. Loosening grip on Danny and Terri. Sarone ties the rope down and moves forward, he raises th tranquilizer crossbow and fires. The bolt cuts the air wi hiss, hitting the snake full in. The snake hisses, a soun not of this earth --

(shouting back) Who's the strongest now? Sarone puts down the crossbow and walks towards the snake with the large mazzle. But the snake isn't ready.to go to sleep. The snake is aggravated. In one fierce movement th snake tosses Danny and Terri like rag dolls, shreds the netting and comes after Sarone. Danny is badly bruised, but his. arms are now free.
Another dose, eh? Sarone is amazingly calm as he loads the crossbow and fir again. This time missing -- the snake lunges at him, knoc the crossbow from his hands. Now Sarone is concerned. .
Shooting Script - December 1 94.

Danpy rips the tape off his legs and helps Terri. Sarone moves fast, racing up a rusty old ladder. The snak follows. Sarone is almost to the top of the ladder...the snake curling around it...climbing quickly...just as Saro is stepping off the ladder, the full weight of the snake tears the rivets from the wall and the ladder, Sarone, an snake fall to the ground with a thunderous crash. Sarone lands hard, but manages to get to his feet. The sn coils, preparing to strike. Sarone screams with primal ra his arms. extended as if he intends to wrestle the massiv reptile. ‘The snake strikes, meeting him head-on with an awesome impact, quickly loops Sarone's body, and begins t squeeze. A machete, hanging from sarone's belt, gets caught betwee the body of Sarone and the body of the snake, cutting int ‘both as the snake powerfully constricts. Sarone struggle his face bright red and bulging, blood dripping from his ears. The snake squeezes tighter, breaking bones are hear Blood erupts from Sarone's mouth and nose.. An eyeball bu obscenely before plopping out of its socket. , Terri and Danny, now free, hide behind a stack of lumbe ‘They watch in horror as the snake opens wide its jaws an begins to swallow Sarone head first.

Danny and Terri creep quietly towards the front doors. Th snake lays still, digesting, between them and the door. A large lump, formerly Sarone, can be seen below the snakes neck. They sneak around a piece of machinery and the snak instantly alert to their movement, its massive tail whipp around, its tongue flicking out. The snake is so big-his bédy, even when partially coiled, seems to be. everywhere. The front doors are blocked by t snake. A crack in the walls to the side are blocked by th snake. Danny and. Terri’ look. over behind them and see t mound full of writhing anacondas. No way they're.climbing over that to get out. They duck back into the shadows.
Ok.. Ok. We gotta get a grip. Terri looks around.
Do you think thet tranquilizer worked? (CONTINUED)

Yeah...like half a beer to you and me.
= Maybe he's done?
You think he won't snack between meals?
I don't know. We're trapped. They exchange a look. : . , S,
Ok. ..How do we kill it? Terri looks up to the second floor.
Maybe there's something up there. Danny: looks around and sees the answer: the fuel drums.
